reviewText: High quality console shooter. Graphics are nice, sound is present, there is even some kind of story. HOWEVER THIS IS NOT A F.E.A.R. GAME AT ALL. All they have to do is to copy the first game and polish graphics - bam, another award-winning shooter. Instead of that devs decided that players like being tacticool - press ACTION TO CREATE A BAD COVER. Walking robot parts are plain boring - w+m1, stop to regen. Weapons feel light (probably because of reloading animations, especially sniper rifle which is made of paper. Speaking of sniper rifle - you can quickscope). At least the enemies seem to be as smart as before (on hard). Unfortunately they are just cannon fodder - walking robot and turret parts will make you yawn. Btw right before the last interval you'll be forced to sit behind the turret to shoot enemies while listening to some generic rock music ( Snake Fist (Instrumental) - look it up on YouTube). Oh, and your dudebro ally will be shouting some nonsense - like I am in CoD or something.\n\nLack of manual saving, weak story, short duration, casualisation - all of this killed the spirit of F.E.A.R. The game is good as a console shooter, I cannot deny that. It is just not the game I was expecting.

reviewText: I find that nearly all horror games have jump-scares, so I went in head first into this game thinking that probably most horror elements would be presented in this way. I had a lot of fun playing Fear 2, it took me 7 hours to beat but it felt longer for some reason. The atmosphere is great, much more environment changes than Fear 1. Great lighting effects, but the textures are ugly. The first thing that came to mind when I played Fear 2 is how similar it is to Doom 3 - the Intels (PDA in Doom 3) laying on the floor, the jump scares, style of the corridors, those moments when a person is being swallowed by Almas darkness or whatever one may call it, and the guns even felt Doom 3-ish to me. Fear 2 also nails the difficulty curve quite well IMO, if you put it on hard its challenging but not frustrating. I think this is a topic often forgotten in many modern games, usually there's too many annoying difficulty spikes or the descriptions at the start about each difficulty are inaccurate. The ending is one sure to be remembered, it's unique.

reviewText:
What is F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin?
--
F.E.A.R. 2 is the successor of F.E.A.R., an immersive psycho-horror FPS with a fantastic bullet time mechanic.
--
--
Who would most enjoy F.E.A.R. 2?
--
If you loved the first F.E.A.R. game, you'll most likely love this title as well. That being said, if you felt the first game was too visually dated for your tastes, or too mechanically clunky, the game has improved leaps and bounds in that department. The game also favors action packed gun-battles a little bit more heavily than the first. The tension is very slightly lighter than the first game, but it holds enough strengths to more than compensate for this.
--
--
Over-all: 80.0%
As a whole, F.E.A.R. 2 is a more solid title than the first game, and will appeal to a wider audience. That being said, some of the elements that make F.E.A.R. 2 a better game as a whole, slightly subtract from the immersive experience that was  the terrifying glory of the first F.E.A.R. game.
--
Mechanics: 4/5
The mechanics are a definiteive improvement here, over the first game. Movement in much more fluid, bullet time is possibly even more smoothly integrated, there's more interaction with the world and terrain, the AI is very well done this  time around, and as a whole, the game feels very appropriately smooth and fluid.
--
Experience: 4/5
In the five years between the release of F.E.A.R. 1 and F.E.A.R. 2, the developers have come along way in improving the audio and visuals of the game. The game went from passibly average looking (just enough so's to not distract from the experience) to downright gorgeous. The textures are fairly average, but  the artistic embellishments in conjunction with the fantastic visual effects definitely help this game shine. The audio has also taken a massive leap, helping tie the experience together. With all that being said, the psycho-horror elements of the game have been toned down just a touch, and that in combination with a few crowd pleaser moments, and the addition of collectible bits of intel, actually subtract from the experience slightly, in my opinion. The game is still fantastically immersive, and will draw you in, unlike many other titles to date, but in comparison with the first title, I feel F.E.A.R. 2 sacrifices a chunk of it's biggest strength -- the raw gripping psycho-horror elements, for a few fun, but unnecessary scripted gun battles.
Balance: 4/5

--
Longevity: 4/5
The game is slightly shorter than the first game in the series, containing only 14 missions of roughly 30-45 minute  length each. That being said, it doesn't rely solely on the immersive experience, unlike the first game, and provides a number little bits of intel for the player to run around and find, if that's your thing. There may be room for a second playthrough with F.E.A.R. 2, between looking to find the rest of the missed bits of intel, playing through on a higher difficulty, or simply just to enjoy the beauty and fluidity of the game for second time.

reviewText: Fun and full of action.  The game is very similar to the original, which is both good and bad, with some new mechanics.  The ability to use the environment to create cover was an impressive addition, but with many of the levels already chock full of available cover it makes this ability pointless.  The game is hallway crawler shooter, there are almost no outdoor levels and its all kinda the same, which was a weakness from the first game.  The shooting and particle effects are top notch similar to the original.  The story behind the game is kinda cut and paste from the first game and the original protagonist is no where to be seen in the game.  Good game on its own merits though, I recommend it.

reviewText: FEAR 2 is, obviously, the sequel to the original FEAR. As with all sequels it enhances some things from the original but isn't as good as the original, and that is true here. The one of the small things that bugged me about this game was that the slow motion wasn't as, well, as slow, as the first game, just a little but it felt weird. The graphics were improved dramatically and I really liked how they looked. As with the first game it combines FPS action elements with horror elements, although not done as well as the first game it still does it adequate. I don't think it's really worth buying though, I got this game along with FEAR 1 and 3 along with the batman arkham games and few other games in the WB games humble bundle charity thing they did a few months prior to this writing, I payed I think 8 dollars (yeah I'm cheap, sue me I'm a high school student). If you want to play a FEAR game buy FEAR 1 instead.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I read alot of people saying...not as good as the first one, not as scary...and I wonder...did they play the same game I did?  I purchased the whole FEAR series as a bundle and I have to say that in terms of overall satifaction, F.E.A.R 2: Project Origin was the best overall in terms of story, content, difficulty, and gameplay.  I know, I know, F.E.A.R was revolutionary for its time and there were alot of things Monolith did right that first time, but F.E.A.R also was extremely repetitive.  There's only so many replica soldiers you could have long drawn out shootouts with before you're looking for the cheat codes to move the story along.  It did set the stage for the 2nd game.

The character of Sgt. Becket was much more thought out and slightly deeper than the Point Man of F.E.A.R, who just received mission after mission with short cut scene here and there.  F.E.A.R. 2 really did a great job of communicating the deeper history of Alma and why she was who she was.  I can't say that I blame her for being as ticked off as she was.  Some of the NPC interaction was a little stiff and generic, but for my money the whole game was a great improvement over the first one.

It's worth a playthrough, just for the ending, which surprised me I admit, but made more sense in F.3.A.R when I played it immediately after.

reviewText:
This is the second episode in the F.E.A.R. trilogy, and a bit of a disappointment. If you've played FPS like Half-Life 2 or Doom 3, nothing about the gameplay will enthrall you. The story is even sillier than the first part, F.E.A.R., and ends most timidly and laughably, especially after subjecting you to quite an intense gunplay barely 5 minutes earlier. The game just can't make up its mind whether the chief villain, Alma, is a victim of a secret military experiment, an alien, or a ghost. How in the hell can hallcinations eat away one's health? But they do in this game. Go figure.

Just like the first game, you are made to shoot your way through several office complexes, underground research facilities, and subway tunnels. There's nothing to do in the game except kill, kill, kill, the waves of enemies obstructing your progress. The game relieves you of all the brain-work and figures your way forward for you. Enemy AI, while not pathetic, is predictable and makes the gameplay boring after a while. You can foretell 8 times out of 10 where the enemy is hiding, from where it is going to emerge, and your best hiding spots. Environs and locations have dull colors and textures and look depressing. One may wonder what the 12GB download size of this game went into since the game is easily completable within 15 hrs. Background music is grating and a nuisance. During gun battles, it prevents you from hearing enemy chatter & movement, and is best turned way down. The sound-mixing too is completely screwed-up. While in the first game, all six channels of the soundtrack worked well and enabled one to ascertain the direction of enemy's approach from the sound of footsteps or radio chatter, sound in this game doesn't seem to have been configured for multi-channel setup. In my experience, a well-configured multi-channel soundtrack is absolutely critical in clearing major gun battles in any intense shooter by assisting in effectively taking out the enemies sneaking up on you. I hope sound mixing engineer was fired for not doing his job properly. Horror element is childish and the game uses cheap jump-scare tactics to shake you up. Difficulty levels are once again messed up, as they were in the first game. HARD setting is hardly hard and difficult to tell apart from the normal setting except for sniper fire and grenades which kill you in one instance. In fact, I found HARD setting easier than the NORMAL setting, but it may be because I played on HARD setting after having played the game on NORMAL, therefore having the advantage of knowing maps and enemy movement in advance. There are other minor flaws and irritants in the game design that further sour the experience, such as, grenades bouncing around like tennis balls, inability to load only the last save point and not the older ones, etc.

Now that I've ripped the game apart, let me mention that the game is not too bad a product on a stand-alone basis, and a typical FPS lover can have fun with it. It's really in comparison to other FPS on the market that it appears dim-witted. Coming from a major studio, one expects a game to deliver a unique and unforgettable experience. Isn't that why we all play video games--because they 'virtually' put us in places & situations where we won't ever find ourselves in real lives? That's why at least I play 'em. This game does that alright, but via an unimaginative design and in a bland style.

I know I won't be playing this game ever again. I also know I'd have at least 3x more fun repeat-playing any game of the Half-Life or Bioshock or Far Cry franchise.

Game played smoothly without a stutter (except freezing twice during the entire gameplay and subsequently self-correcting on its own) on a Win 10 machine and a GTX 960 OC card.

RECOMMENDED to newbie FPS players. For veterans, AVOID. 6/10.

reviewText:
The best of both games on either side of this release. I personally think this is the best F.E.A.R. overall as it is graphically impressive enough not to be plain to look at, the game story and mood is very faithful to the original. It feels like a modern version of the first FEAR game. The design choices are a little different than the first FEAR which some people might not like.

I know a lot of people miss the high contrast lighting that was traded for a more realistic, ambient lighting style, which I think is a fair complaint, as the old lighting was pretty cool. In terms of the overall graphics however, #2 as a whole is far superior.

Multiplayer is dead, only purchase if you want to play the single player campaign.

reviewText:
This game gave a grown man nightmares...

FEAR 2 is one of my favorite games of all time.
To me it was brutally scary.  I have a thing about paranormal, evil demons, etc. so this game pushes that button.  Hard.
It just does everything right and it gets even worse as you get through it.
Even to a point where the horror element at one point becomes ultimate.  As in it doesn't get worse.  You will know what I mean when your there.
Not to mention all the other crazy cool stuff that goes on.  I won't spoil it, but there is quite a bit of action.  And the back story about the corporation and it's evil deeds...  fantastic!  Creepy all the way.
As long as it's night, the lights are off and your by yourself, or course.  Otherwise don't buy horror games because your a girl.  My little Pony has a large selection.   :)
Just kidding.  Lots of people don't think this is scary at all, for some reason.  I dunno, it scarred me.  That's for sure.
It wouldn't hurt to play the first one first.  To know what's going on with the story.
But forget the third one.  Unless your a fan.  It's really dumb.  Complete contrast to this game.

reviewText:
This recommendation is for the players that finished F.E.A.R. 1.

I must admit that F.E.A.R. 2 was less interesting than the first one in many points. Even if the graphics were upgraded, and even if they understood one thing or two about level building (not making compounds too huge so the player doesn't feel like they will never get out of it).

The story was less interesting because of the lack of mystery. In F.E.A.R. 1, you never truly understood what was happening, and it was this that make you continue. You wanted to know what was about to happen next. The sequel just makes you wandering throught compounds, outside environnements and an elementary school to find one people or an other. The presence of Alma is fast explained (in my opinion) so you don't need to find out anything by yourself.

The horror moments, that were truly horrific sometimes in F.E.A.R. 1, are lacking solidity in Project Origin. It is way more direct, like representations of Alma attacking you, and hardly any shadows on the walls or any moments of chill throught your spine (elements that were doing really great work previously).

I am still recommending it since it is a great FPS, the weapons are upgraded and less precise (in F.E.A.R. 1, the weapons were stupidly precise, the pistol was the best weapon in the game), and the environnement are really well done.

reviewText: Building upon the story of F.E.A.R. core story (excluding the expansions, sadly) you pick up shortly before the end of the first title. This sequel is a bit of mixed emotions for me, personally. The game introduces a sprint as well as Iron sight aiming familiar with other modern shooters, and retains the SloMo mechanics. Story begins as a different character who had showed signs of being able to be a psychic commander not unlike Fettel and thus is thrown into a multitude of tests and challenges to confirm it. How I felt this title lost a bit of its identity by switching to another developer, as well as story not quite likable or the NPC's either. Though there are some aspects that really called true to the genre. I would get this if its on sale, a damn good sale at that.

reviewText:
It has a much better graphic than the first. Alma is a *lot* better. But there are fewer horror scenes, and they're not so intense.

I've ended it on hard level, and it wasn't hard at all. 80% of the time you'll beat all the enemies using Slow-Mo. The other 20% are real hard parts, like the Training Center, the Wagon, and the arrival at Still Island.

Also, crouching doesn't save you from being shot when you're behind an obstacle. What's the point on crouching then? It is not possible to lie on the floor too.

Putting these cons aside, it's a really nice game.

reviewText:
Gone is the intrigue. Gone is the intelligent gunfights. Gone is the sense of 'FEAR'.

FEAR 2 is unfortunately a game that virtually feels lost during its development. Monolith is the studio who made the popular Shogan game previous to FEAR, and FEAR 2 is some kind of bizarre cross-over. The franchise at this point has become lost in translation. It no longer has the slow pace, building tension, between amazing gunfights. The whole game has become a B-movie sci-fi chiller. Enemies now consist of dumb sparsely populated goons in crappy generic-looking masks.

But as initially fun as it may seem to jump into a mechanical military exo-suit, and start blowing everything up - you soon realise Monolith have succumbed to the Call Of Duty cliché. The fun wears off very quick and you remember you wanted to play FEAR, not Mechwarrior.

It's a damn shame. FEAR with its smart enemies should have been the template for future FPS games but instead we're stuck with dumb AI and scripted events thanks to the obsession of console-oriented games (COD).

I can only reommend this on the strength of a half decent FPS, it nearly has nothing in common with the first game. Big disappointment.

reviewText:
F.E.A.R 2 Project Origin, is a game where fear is really not an issue. Although one of the best shooters around, the fear factor is not the one i would appreciate in a game like this. True there are scary moments, but the game's basic core is the awesome gunfights and the bloodbath that follows. Even a scary sex hungry ghost seems kinda little, when you face her with:

1 Lasers (Big deal, nobody is afraid of a big red beam that pierces everything!)
2 Plasma Guns (So what if you can explode everyone with a single shot!)
3 Apb Turret ( This is the reason why Arnold will hate you...)
4 Mecha Armors (Cause if using an armored suit filled with machine guns and missiles cant guarantee you victory, then you are doing it wrong!!!)

Also, if you ever feel like the game is really challenging, you get to use super slow motion to help you make the fights easier and more enjoyable (You get to splatter people like that and become a monster yourself ^^).

The story is big and kinda generic with an ending that will make you wanna peck your eyes out, but still it was fun to play. If nothing else i got to feel like rambo ^^

If you want to buy this game for a spooky ride dont, cause you will be terribly disappointed. If you on the other hand  want it for a pure shooting fest, by all means dont let it w8ing. You will love it!!!

reviewText: The sequel to one of my favorite FPS games. This game feels like it was made to make the series more accessible for people. The guns are changed this time around to make the game feel easier when in gunfights. The A.I. is not as impressive as the first game unfortunately. It's not bad, but it has been toned down a bit. The grenade particle effects are also gone from the first game :(\n\nIt's not all bad though! The long cooridor filled levels from the first game are gone. This game is changing it up every level. You even get to control an awesome mech to go down streets blowing up everything. This game is more difficult than the first one, mainly due to not being able to quicksave anymore. It has a checkpoint system this time around, which balances the game a lot better. The scares in this game feel even more terrifying this time around. The school easily has some of the scariest moments I have ever seen in a game. The new enemy types love to pop out constantly when you are least expecting it. The graphics have also got a nice upgrade. The deployable turrets were a fun new weapon, but I wish I got to use them more. The game is about 8 hours long, depending on how much you explore.

reviewText:
F.E.A.R. was an incredible game with an AI the likes of which had never been seen. It had a decent enough of a storyline that acted as a great vehicle for getting to explore a very Akira-esque underground facility. It's still visually stunning to this day (I played it a few months back).

All of those traits are dumped for F.E.A.R. 2. An alarming percentage of the enemies will stand off in the distance as you shoot them repeatedly in the head. If they aren't standing perfectly still, they will abandon cover and run straight at you. The storyline  is much more limited than the first. While I think the J-horror jump scares of the original were pretty dumb, the story was at least compelling enough to create a real sympathy for Alma. Alma plays a minor role at most in Project Origin, with the devs perferring you to have a strong bond with your mindless, soulless teammates while giving you no reason to feel connected to them except by telling you how close you all are. All of the imagination that went into the original facility is gone here. The sense of scale has been scaled down, if you will, to a couple of small buildings and an itty bitty underground lab.

Everything about it feels more like an ambitious yet terrible expansion pack than a real sequel. If you adore the original as much as I do, I would definitely suggest you just appreciate it and it's second expansion pack, Perseus Mandate, and leave F.E.A.R. 2 alone as to not spoil your fondness for the original.

reviewText: After the stellar FEAR, I was interested to play FEAR2 and see how it would compare.  One of the main issues in FEAR was the lack of variety in the environment. This is thankfully fixed in FEAR2! With varying environments such as schools, clubs and hospitals. Also the fun slow motion combat still remains intact thankfully. Also the environment graphics and paranormal effects are really well done. However the horror is still the same, maybe creepy sometimes but never really gets scary, even with obligitory cheap jump scares! The story is bland and the ending is not only really dumb but exposes plot holes in the story. Also the game has been made rather mainstream in comparision to FEAR, with no save anywhere features, a focus on large set pieces and lots of quick time events which is a shame. But it's still a fun game if you're a fan of the FEAR series and of FPS's in general, hell you could do alot worse anyway!

reviewText:
F.E.A.R. 2 takes place concurrently (only for a short time) and during the aftermath of the first F.E.A.R. You play a SFOD soldier named Becket whose team is grabbed by Armacham, juiced full of experimental drugs, and then sent on a mission to stop Alma while chasing down leads on the how and the why of it all. You get the gist of the story in radio communications and in-game cutscenes but all the details are in logs scattered throughout the levels, similar to the first game but there's a lot of more of them this time.

F.E.A.R. had amazing graphics at the time and Project Origin doesn't disappoint. The effects are similar to the first game with lots of sparks and dust when the bullets fly. The best looking effects come when you're having hallucinations. Colors fade, return, your view goes blurry and sharp, lights flash on and off. It's impossible to describe effectively.

A big complaint about the first game was the lack of variety in environments. It was a lot of offices and industrial areas. Personally it didn't bother me much, but Monolith took it to heart. Of course there's more offices and industrial parks but there's also a school, a medical facility, research labs, and the destroyed streets of Auburn. You never feel like you're walking the same corridors over and over and no one environment really overstays its welcome.

F.E.A.R. 2 also has the same fantastic gunplay that the first game had. Enemies are quasi-intelligent in dropping for cover and flanking your positions. That said, on normal difficulty, the game never gets too hard. I don't think I died a single time. Between the abundance of armor and health packs, the whole game is just a little easy. The only nuance that threw me at the beginning is that when you hit the slo-mo button on and off, there's a little bit of a spin-up and spin-down. It was basically an on-off switch in the first game so having a second of delay really threw me off at the beginning.

My favorite part of this game were the areas where you get to stomp around in the elite power armor. It isn't just for the amazing amounts of firepower the elite power armor brings, or the carnage of the fights you get into with it, but the effects while you're in it. As it takes more damage, alarms scream, the screen gets distorted, and warnings flash manically. It's a hell of a lot of fun and really makes me clamor for Monolith to make good on the easter eggs it's put in recent games and make a sequel to SHOGO: Mobile Armor Division, a mech game they made a decade ago.

There's no easier way to put it: F.E.A.R. 2 is an awesome first-person shooter. I played through it all in a single day, which is a task I don't think I've ever done. It's basically amazing.

reviewText: OVERALL THOUGHTS:\nA good game that has two brilliant gameplay facets, that are let down by several smaller problems. However it shouldn't ruin the experience too much, as those brilliant gameplay facets
date:
are really freaking awesome. Would recommend, definitely.

STORY:
You play as a man named Becket who, despite actually having a name, is as quiet and as the Point Man from FEAR 1. The game begins right before it's predecessor ends, with Becket and a team of soldiers trying to find and secure Armacham employee Genevieve Aristide. After a simple first level that teaches you the basics of gameplay and gives you a few good scares, the operation goes south when the entire city is levelled from the nuke Point Man detonates in FEAR 1. You wake up in a hospital and discover you and your teammates have been experimented on, against your will, and now Alma is drawn to you, as well as a very stereotypical sergeant with all of armacham's military might intent on wiping out Genevieve Aristide, you, and anybody else who could spill the beans on the company's bad deeds. The over-arching story is a little nonsensical but is presented dramatically and it's very, very well done (except for a few not-so-good voice actors along the way) so it is forgivable. The story also expands on Alma Wade, the figurehead of the series, and turns her from spooky ghost girl into a character you actually can feel very sorry for, until her naked, wrinkled corpse begins hunting you and trying to... do things to you... The ending of the game is actually really good though, and even though I knew what was coming, I couldn't help but still be a little freaked out. It WILL make you want to either replay the game, or go and buy F3AR (Yes, they spell it like that).

GAMEPLAY:
The gameplay is pretty similar to the first game. It's a first person shooter with a heavy emphasis on strategic combat against squads of intelligent AI but also comes with levels that aren't just corridors (and encourage exploration), as well as some truly horrifying sequences. Unfortunately the game is a little uneven in some regards, as the action-shooty-shoot-bang side of the game feels rough compared to FEAR 1 with the AI seeming less intense and almost less intelligent , and a lot of the new features feel shallow and useless. However the enemies are still fun to fight, and are still much smarter than the average COD campaign AI. You won't use the optional Flip cover" mechanic at all

reviewText:
F.E.A.R.2: Project Origin is the sequel of F.E.A.R.
The story takes up place near the ending for the stpry of F.E.A.R. and then goes on.

For a story it is nice, there are some interesting stuff going on like letting the player find out details about how Alma was born and what happened to her. During the game you will find intel that explains various interesting situations.

The game is not scary enough. Gamers have gotten used to any kind of horror these years, but it is still nice. The guns and the graphics are very good.

The game also includes a small expantion named Reborn" which lets the player take the place of a replica soldier that goes rogue. His role is to meet with Paxton Fettel in the very end. The story doesnt offer any special information or extra meaning at all

reviewText: F.E.A.R 2 is one of those really wierd titles. It doesn't feel like a sequel so much as just a remake of the original with more consolized design. All the maps are more linear, it looks more like Call of Duty and there's a flagrant amount of gun porn.\n\nIt's gameplay resembles the original superficially but it's style is in stark contrast. With regard to how well those elements are incorporated that's totally up to the player's discretion. Needless to say it's not one of the worst games I've ever played, I just think it lacks it's own identity.

reviewText: OVERALL THOUGHTS:\nA good game that has two brilliant gameplay facets, that are let down by several smaller problems. However it shouldn't ruin the experience too much, as those brilliant gameplay facets
date:
are really freaking awesome. Would recommend, definitely.

STORY:
You play as a man named Becket who, despite actually having a name, is as quiet and as the Point Man from FEAR 1. The game begins right before it's predecessor ends, with Becket and a team of soldiers trying to find and secure Armacham employee Genevieve Aristide. After a simple first level that teaches you the basics of gameplay and gives you a few good scares, the operation goes south when the entire city is levelled from the nuke Point Man detonates in FEAR 1. You wake up in a hospital and discover you and your teammates have been experimented on, against your will, and now Alma is drawn to you, as well as a very stereotypical sergeant with all of armacham's military might intent on wiping out Genevieve Aristide, you, and anybody else who could spill the beans on the company's bad deeds. The over-arching story is a little nonsensical but is presented dramatically and it's very, very well done (except for a few not-so-good voice actors along the way) so it is forgivable. The story also expands on Alma Wade, the figurehead of the series, and turns her from spooky ghost girl into a character you actually can feel very sorry for, until her naked, wrinkled corpse begins hunting you and trying to... do things to you... The ending of the game is actually really good though, and even though I knew what was coming, I couldn't help but still be a little freaked out. It WILL make you want to either replay the game, or go and buy F3AR (Yes, they spell it like that).

GAMEPLAY:
The gameplay is pretty similar to the first game. It's a first person shooter with a heavy emphasis on strategic combat against squads of intelligent AI but also comes with levels that aren't just corridors (and encourage exploration), as well as some truly horrifying sequences. Unfortunately the game is a little uneven in some regards, as the action-shooty-shoot-bang side of the game feels rough compared to FEAR 1 with the AI seeming less intense and almost less intelligent , and a lot of the new features feel shallow and useless. However the enemies are still fun to fight, and are still much smarter than the average COD campaign AI. You won't use the optional Flip cover" mechanic at all

reviewText:
Yet more FEAR

Pro:
Very good atmosphere
Demo (TY devs)
OK story
Single & multi player

Con:
Expensive
Jump scare is not scary
No steam cards - achieves
Like several of these FPS game after 1/2 hour I start to get hot and sick - something about the bob or graphics. Only happens with some FPS games.  This is one of them. Just a note.
You should really play #1 to understand #2
Freaking Expensive
Unbalanced



Overall:
5/10 (+1 atmosphere, +2 demo, -1 no steam stuff, -2 price - should be $5 with DLC) = 5/10

Yet another thumbs sideways.

If you like FPS with atmosphere and can get the collection 90%(+) off grab it.  For me this is at best an average FPS with OK atmosphere.  Is it worth $15 CDN? No.  Is the DLC with another $10? No.  If you get it in a bundle play it.  If you can get the collection cheap ... even better.  Take a weekend and just enjoy it.

For me it's thumbs down just for the price. $25 CDN for the game + DLC is just too steep. $55 CDN for the collection is excessive.  If the game + dlc drops to $5 or the collection for $15 then I'll go thumbs up.

That said.  TY for the Demo.  Every dev should post a demo.

reviewText:
Dull, repetitive, and uninteresting.

I had little expectations when I started playing F.E.A.R. 2, but i had thought the series sounded interesting and wanted to play the first game when it came out. Playing this game was still a disappointment. The levels were dull and uninteresting in design and layout. The characters all dull and two-dimensional, not to mention very stereotypical. What could be claimed as a plot and setting were poorly presented, badly paced and left me wanting it over not even half-way through. There was no scariness, no tension. Jump scares were continually accompanied by violin screeches, and were ineffective. The ending was disturbing, and didn't make much sense until I looked at some videos on youtube after about it. Even then it feels like it was mostly disconnected from the rest of the game. The possible attempt at adding atmosphere by having the HUD flicker was very annoying, bothered my eyes and since it didn't extend to anything besides the player's HUD and flashlight it felt like it was meant to punish the player more than be atmospheric.

Playing through on normal difficulty I found there were more than enough health and armor pickups to almost be constantly at full health. Weapons were frustrating because of the number found in game, the limit to the number able to be carried and their blandness, none really stood out for power or accuracy or usefulness beyond what ammo was most plentiful. At least one weapon had no other ammo besides the 5 shots it had when given. Grenades felt weak and mostly useless. (shock grenades were the only type consistently useful).

The boss fights were moderately interesting. The AI was interesting, the use of cover was fine, but the randomly running between cover spots, or the often indecisive movement of the AI trying to choose a spot to run to for cover were a pain. The powered armor sequences were even more linear and dull, and there was a greater tempation to not use the armor when available to try and give myself something challenging. I also went through most of the game without using the bullet-time ability very much. It didn't really seem needed for very much. There is also only about 6-7 different types of enemies, most of which are similar soldier types.

reviewText:
A mediocre game that simply isn't worth the time when there are so many good games out there.
The shooting is unsatisfying, with boring enemies, dissapointingly vanilla weapons and an over reliance on the Slow-motion gimick to the exclusion of almost anything else.
The level design is completely on-rails and almost exclusively takes place in dark, ruined corridors.
The horror aspect is tame and one never truly feels that a malevolent psionic god-child poses any real threat to them.
The story, what little of it is presented is full of bland, boring characters whose only purpose seems to be to die horribly moments after the narrative focuses on them making it hard to get invested in the tale.
Despite this, it's a functional game but one that only too well shows it's console origins and suffers horribly from a lack of ambition.
voteText: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
To sum it up, its a generic FPS thats based off the original but in no way recreates it or really continues the lineage of FEAR but rather takes inspiration from that game in the form of bullets on a powerpoint. Its not bad, I have played far worse but its definetly not good either.

It felt like they looked at F.E.A.R. and just made a casualised/consolised version of the game instead of taking the first game and building onto that.

Unfortunately it dousn't take anything that was good from the first game and build onto that and feels more like a generic FPS of these days rather than anything like the, now classic, original. The great AI is gone and feels much more basic now while they still attempt to recreate the original they feel much more stupid. The maps have alot more detail but sit at either at being simplistic places to run through or overly complicated areas where you get turned around and confused where to go. The areas though do look nice and the graphics in general are a huge jump forward in fidelity but something is lost in the transfer. The 1st game had a very flat and empty graphical design (either due to intended design or hardware limits of the time) that added towards the atmosphere which is lost with 2.

There is also alot more involvement with NPCs but unfortunately the story isn't exactly the easiest to understand or make sense at all. Honestly with this type of story there isn't much sense to be made and its more of a thriller than a story book.

The scaryness isn't really there aside from a handfull of jump and other scares but its not a scary game anymore than the first and probably less so. Its mainly a shooter like the original game, but you end up fighting the same enemies over and over and scenarios reminiscent of the original game. Unfortunately the AI of the old game and feeling of a dynamic shootout escapes this one as the experience feels more canned than homemade.

I would only recommend playing this if you just played FEAR and want more of that type of game or if you just want to play a generic style FPS and know what your getting into.

The cinematics and writing is pretty good, but if you wanting something super serious all the way through than the writing will fail you from the very start of the game. But it tries to be serious at certain points but its hard to care about the characters in a game where the gameplay feels generic and bland.

Its also very easy, for the most part you can either just blaze through areas or take advantage of faults in the AI to get past enemies more easily.

Meh

reviewText: A Linear, on-rails shooter that tries very hard to bring horror and symbolism to first person shooters. It stumbles upon itself and seems confused as to whether it wants to be an action game, a cleverly crafted horror game, or a jumpscare simulator. The shooting mechanics are stale, the guns feel like toys, the characters aren't very likable and the plot makes little to no sense.\n\nThere are worst shooters out there, but there shouldn't be any reason to settle for this either.

reviewText:
Best follow-up sequel to the F.E.A.R franchise.

Project Origin offers a new and exciting plot with new and interesting characters. They remain interesting due to the slow and convincing character developement. Dialogue is great. Weapons are well adjusted and incredibly consistent to use. The environment of Project Origin is a lot more interactive leaving you with a rush of adrenaline and emotions.

In my opinion this game is the best in the series and had much more potential than the F.E.A.R and its sequel F.E.A.R 3.

reviewText:
Singleplayer

Yeah I just finished the story and I have to say, good job Monolith Studios. This sequel was a worthy continuation of the F.E.A.R. story. People who played the first part (as I did) will feel like they are coming home. If you played the first part everything will be familiar and you know most of the enemies and you will know most of the weapons that are available.

The graphics are a bit outdated, but WHO cares when the story is awesome. I have to admit, Almas jumpscares couldn`t get me as bad as in the previous F.E.A.R. game. Because they were basically the same....

But yes, I`ve seen parts in the game that made me really smile and think: Holy crap this is nicely done (school part) and some horror-movie directors should take this as example and maybe make better movies. But yes, thats another story. All in all I recommend this to ALL F.E.A.R. fans and people who dont mind about graphically outdated, brutal shooter-action, which this game can deliver easily.

Multiplayer

*Dead*

Sad but that is the truth. Wanted to give it a go, but there is not one server online. Checked it multiple times.

Rather a disappointment, it did not live up to the very high standards set by the first F.E.A.R.
I can not write that I would not recommend it (especially at a budget price) but STEAM leaves no other option than yes/no. If I could I would go for neutral".
"

reviewText:
Worse than the predecessor in nearly every way. Since the armor takes forever to deplete if you even try to take cover, the game is way too easy. The weapons aren't nearly as fun to use as before and cool stuff like dual wielding pistols or the cool lighting gun have been removed. The combat is just meh at best.

The Alma scenes have been improved from the predecessor and there are some cool moments but they don't feel as threatening and atmospheric as before. In fact, the game feels dull pretty much all the time. It feels like playing a generic shooter with slowdown mechanic and a random girl walking around.

Not to mention that this game plus the DLC took just as much time for me to beat as Extraction Point expansion for the first Fear, and unlike Extraction Point, this game isn't worth replaying because the combat is so forgettable.

Just stick to the first Fear and pretend this one doesn't exist.

reviewText:
F.E.A.R. 2 is a big step up from the first game in many ways. It provides a more cinematic look as opposed to the first game's rough, arcade style. It's considerably scarier, shifting some of its focus towards more tangible horrors and fine-tuning its brand of psychological horror. It's prettier, with high-poly models, realistic animations, and a whole range of pretty shaders. F.E.A.R. 2 is a better game than its predecessor. It's a game that has finally learned how to scare you, even if that means abandoning pure psychological horror for a more threatening approach. It's not a game riddled with jump scares either. While the slow-mo takes off some of the horror edge, encounters with the new enemies and navigating the new setpieces is very frightening.

As usual, the game's plot seriously sags in the middle, but I think the only real problem with the game is that the ending is so abrupt and disappointing. There's almost no buildup, and the final fight of the game is far too easy and builds almost no tension. And then, it abruptly ends. The game itself is short, which gives the game no room for pacing aside from moving between horror bits, action bits, and story bits. In fact, aside from the very ending, there's nothing new brought to the table here, story-wise. Just some backstory you don't need to know or could have already picked up from the first game.

Despite F.E.A.R. 2's lackluster plot, short length and abrupt ending, it's a good game. The combat is as fluid as ever, the game feels more broad with its increased horror and cinematics, and the visuals and sounds have been spit-shined for a nice finish. If plot isn't your thing and you just want a good, tense, shooter, then F.E.A.R. 2 will deliver that and then some.

reviewText: Let's get serious here. I'm putting on my serious face for this review, as FEAR is my second favorite FPS of all time right behind Fallout 3. FEAR 2, I should start out by saying, is not a bad game. It's decent compared to any other FPS you play these days, but what ends up making it a pile of waste to be trudged through is when you compare it to the original FEAR. For instance, a common theme in FEAR 1 is that when you kill a enemy in slow-motion, they often die still fireing the gun, allowing you to be clipped if you're not careful enough. In FEAR 2, I only saw that happen exactly 5 times. All the guns in FEAR 2 sound like BB guns, and aren't satisfying to use, whilst in FEAR 1 you actually fired bullets instead of what sounds like nerf darts. Also the shotgun got downgraded, and that is just a crime. The only part that I thought FEAR 2 did get right was the setting, but that was only for the School portion of the game. All in all, FEAR 2 is a okay game, but does not live up to the expectations of the FEAR franchise. 5/10.

reviewText:
Pretty damn good game. Short but sweet. While not entirely bug-free, it's a lot more polished than its prequel. The game also seems to be a bit more clever with its scares, making the scary bits a lot more enjoyable.

The level design is on par with the original FEAR, though a little more varied. Paths to objectives are unrealistically complex, but fun nonetheless.

Combat is different. The AI seems to be less intelligent but can handle more damage and is more accurate when shooting. Some enemies towards the end can take a bit too much damage to my liking, but not to the point where it gets frustrating. There is no more peeking from cover, meaning you can't fight the same as you did in the original FEAR. On the other hand, it's much easier to flank enemies than it is in the original. While I prefer the original combat and enemies, I don't dislike the ones in FEAR 2. With the exception of fighting monsters, that is.

The game's biggest fault, is that they wanted to include more enemy variety and ended up with some complete BS monsters. There's the fast-but-weak creepy-crawly monsters that are just an annoyance because they do so little damage but are hard to hit and the puppeteer monster that takes a ♥♥♥♥♥on of damage, keeps running away and has the most annoying attack in the world. The latter monster is challenging, sure, but also a real chore.

The story is pretty fun, until you start to think about it and you discover some things that don't quite make sense (or aren't adequately explained, at least). The original game was the same, though.

Both FEAR and FEAR 2 are must-plays.

reviewText: As a sequel, this game expands the story nicely, though the gameplay (except for using objects as cover) is weaker than in the first game. This is a very linear, console shooter. Game looks okay in terms of graphics, paranormal effects are really nice and I think sound is great, though level design - especially at the start - is just uninspired and boring. The scares are even more predictable. Overall, I think the first game is better, but this one is not bad either.

reviewText:
I like F.E.A.R. 2 better than the first game. The atmosphere isn't quite as good, but this game has a much bigger focus on story. I also find all of the guns useful in this game, whereas most of them were not so great in the first. The shooting mechanics are solid.

The graphics are pretty ridiculous. There's so much detail to the world, so much variety. Awesome.

I like the new enemies in this game. The enemy A.I. is not super smart like in the first game, but it's not awful either. The gameplay gets slightly more varied this time around, with a couple of badass moments. The ending owns.

The DLC campaign (Reborn) is very short. Not really worth playing. Nothing new in terms of gameplay.

8/10

reviewText:
I like F.E.A.R. 2 better than the first game. The atmosphere isn't quite as good, but this game has a much bigger focus on story. I also find all of the guns useful in this game, whereas most of them were not so great in the first. The shooting mechanics are solid.

The graphics are pretty ridiculous. There's so much detail to the world, so much variety. Awesome.

I like the new enemies in this game. The enemy A.I. is not super smart like in the first game, but it's not awful either. The gameplay gets slightly more varied this time around, with a couple of badass moments. The ending owns.

The DLC campaign (Reborn) is very short. Not really worth playing. Nothing new in terms of gameplay.

8/10

reviewText: Had fun with the original? Whether your answer is yes or no, it doesn't matter. F.E.A.R. 2 introduces new players to the series with the flawless combat system and smooth controls perfectly, while still keeping fans of the original entertained. F.E.A.R. 1's combat system was already exceptional, and F.E.A.R 2 only improved on it. Overall the story has a lot od depth and is interesting, the graphics were outstanding for its time and are still comparable to some more modern games. Although it feels somewhat less scary than F.E.A.R. 1, playing this game still manages to be a spine chilling experience for me. Definitely worth a try.

reviewText: The game is much maliged by long term fans, though I don't really understand it. The game has all the essentials that the first one did. It  may not seem to push the envelope technologically as its predecessor did, but  FEAR 2 isn't a slouch in that regard either. In all, I enjoyed the act of PLAYING much more with this sequel. FEAR was a great game, and it wowed us all with its chip melting tech, but it also felt flimsy at times, almost like being in a diarama, however beautiful. FEAR 2 is solid, like a rock. It has weight, and more importantly, it has colour. What was excised from the formula has, I think, done more to strengthen the gameplay than weaken it. And it's ironic that critics bemoan the perceived loss of certain atmospheric and narrative elements in favour of increased action. Let's face it, FEAR was never 'scary'. It was tense, sure, but Condemned - THAT'S a scary Monolith game. The FEAR series has always been primarily for the action, and this second game delivers.

reviewText:
Good game. I started out playing this before i played F.E.A.R. and it was then and still a really nice game. It is less scary than it is creepy in its atmosphere. The scariest thing in the entire game were the replica assassins, while everything else was either weird or creepy. But even with that the game was really nice to play because of this aesthetic. The multiplayer if not laggy can be extremely fun when played with a lot of people or with a few friends, and if you like an unsettling industrial atmosphere with fps this provides the perfect setting for that. As far as i remember though, the multiplayer was almost non-existent after a few months back of its release and after the more recent release on the humble indie bundle in nov 2013 it might gave a small kick to the revival of the multiplayer, i can't confirm that it will always be as active as it did on release. The multiplayer is really fun, but unfortunately people find other new gen alternatives and maybe even the gloomy atmosphere turns them off.
I played this game on the highest difficulty and though some parts can get very difficult, especially near the end, it was very satisfying taking on interestingly designed enemy encounters and overcoming them by being smart about using your surroundings and your weapons. The slow motion perk can be an added help if you're encountering rough situations, but i almost never used it for an added challenge, so if you want the real tactical experience i suggest not using it either even though the option is there. If you don't compare this to F.E.A.R. you will see that this game is really great. Most who played this game though, usually played F.E.A.R. and had to compare it with a bias, which had a lower scoring mostly due to its lesser scare factor. It's definitely not as scary as F.E.A.R. and since it is not developed by the same developers of F.E.A.R. the story became slightly more nonsensical in actually making sense of the whole situation and explaining it, which was left as a mini objective of picking up notes around levels to make sense as to why the projects were happening and what was involved in the project but for the most part remained as cryptic as it was nonsensical until you saw the actual cutscenes, and this heavily reflected in F.E.A.R. 3 where the nonsense literally went too far. But aside from that as a developmental story it did well in clouding the experiments in mystery and the hypothetical.

In summary, If you like a dark atmosphere and a polished fps with tactical situations, this is a game for you.
4/5

reviewText:
Good game. I started out playing this before i played F.E.A.R. and it was then and still a really nice game. It is less scary than it is creepy in its atmosphere. The scariest thing in the entire game were the replica assassins, while everything else was either weird or creepy. But even with that the game was really nice to play because of this aesthetic. The multiplayer if not laggy can be extremely fun when played with a lot of people or with a few friends, and if you like an unsettling industrial atmosphere with fps this provides the perfect setting for that. As far as i remember though, the multiplayer was almost non-existent after a few months back of its release and after the more recent release on the humble indie bundle in nov 2013 it might gave a small kick to the revival of the multiplayer, i can't confirm that it will always be as active as it did on release. The multiplayer is really fun, but unfortunately people find other new gen alternatives and maybe even the gloomy atmosphere turns them off.
I played this game on the highest difficulty and though some parts can get very difficult, especially near the end, it was very satisfying taking on interestingly designed enemy encounters and overcoming them by being smart about using your surroundings and your weapons. The slow motion perk can be an added help if you're encountering rough situations, but i almost never used it for an added challenge, so if you want the real tactical experience i suggest not using it either even though the option is there. If you don't compare this to F.E.A.R. you will see that this game is really great. Most who played this game though, usually played F.E.A.R. and had to compare it with a bias, which had a lower scoring mostly due to its lesser scare factor. It's definitely not as scary as F.E.A.R. and since it is not developed by the same developers of F.E.A.R. the story became slightly more nonsensical in actually making sense of the whole situation and explaining it, which was left as a mini objective of picking up notes around levels to make sense as to why the projects were happening and what was involved in the project but for the most part remained as cryptic as it was nonsensical until you saw the actual cutscenes, and this heavily reflected in F.E.A.R. 3 where the nonsense literally went too far. But aside from that as a developmental story it did well in clouding the experiments in mystery and the hypothetical.

In summary, If you like a dark atmosphere and a polished fps with tactical situations, this is a game for you.
4/5

reviewText:
F.E.A.R 2 improves upon the first one in many ways, with the good outweighing the bad. A main complaint is the absence of peek and lean, which is by no means a game breaker, a lesser one is that while the new weapons are extremely fun to use, they could have done a bit more innovating with this game's counterparts to the older weapons - certain are not as fun to shoot anymore. However, things like the laser and the main rifle being much more enjoyable than the rifle in F.E.A.R (assault, not the ASP) make up for it.

Great pacing, narrative, production values (although still some things particularly in the sound department are inconsistent but that's something it shares with the first game). The game changes enough to offer a new experience without getting rid of the F.E.A.R feel - the largest improvement being that much of what was previously endless office buildings are now more varied and engaging.

I consider this to be the final true game in the series.

reviewText:
F.E.A.R. 2 doesn't really do anything thaaat new as an FPS.  But it does the FPS thing very well.

The main thing is how atmospheric the game is.  The combat might be relatively fast (even with the slomo powers), but the game beckons you to stop and look around once it's over.  And for such a linear game, there is always quite a bit to look at and take in.

I liked the first F.E.A.R. game because of the atmosphere and level of detail, as well.  But it suffered from a small budget.  The studio was able to make a lot more assets for F.E.A.R. 2, so the settings are much more varied.  So essentially, here, they did the thing I liked about the first game, but more.

Also, the game runs really well even on ♥♥♥♥♥♥ hardware, despite how good it looks, so that's another plus.

reviewText:
A bit worse for wear than the decade old originals. They polished the game up only to sprinkle little particles of crap on top of it.

List of crap

1)Snipers

2)Armor takes an eternity to whittle down but you can go from full health to dead in an instant. Once you lose all your armor watch the ♥♥♥♥ out.

3)Psuedo-cutscene gemoetry movement that instantly kills you. Don't let the moving car tap you on the toes or you die

4) The hammerhead gun is a piece of ♥♥♥♥. Enemies can tank 4 of these to the head and still keep coming. ♥♥♥♥ off

5) The base shotguns are overpowered and of course the game doesn't give you enough ammo for it to go around

6) You get your first sniper rifle, the only gun that grants properly damaging headshots, during the last hour of gameplay

7) You can only hold onto 3 guns at once lol. Naturally you only pick up ammo for the gun you're weidling at the time

8) No proper final boss

9) The last two minutes of gameplay before the credits start to roll. 20 invisible, impossibly fast enemies vs 1 of you, and you don't have enough slomotion or effective bullets to go around and they can kill you in a literal instant anywhere since there's no effective cover.  I ultimately just ran past that screen and pressed the button-of-game-ending rather than combat them a TENTH time QUICK TEAM WE DON'T HAVE A FINAL BOSS JUST SPAWN A WHOLE BUNCH MORE ENEMIES THAN USUAL

10) In fact just about every encounter can be skipped if you just run past and are clever enough to see/find the exit

11) You can only hold 3 medpacks and a very finite number of grenades/ammo

12) No minigun other than the turret

13) Terrible mech-driving segments coupled with vasoline-o-vision

14) Women in combat roles, let alone the 1st Seargant, AND the only one who survives to the very ♥♥♥♥ing end

15) SHE ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ OUT IN THE LAST SECOND AND DOESN'T KILL THE PERSON WHO'S RESPONSIBLE FOR EVERYTHING EVEN THOUGH SHE'S RIGHT THERE WHAT THE ♥♥♥♥ IS CQC AND THEN DIES LIKE A ♥♥♥♥♥ SOMEONE PLEASE FOR THE LOVE OF GOD GET BOSS ON THE LINE

16) ♥♥♥♥ every semblance of plot this game tries to shoehorn into reality. That's just what I wanna do is read a whole bunch of pdfs with worthless information in between gunbattles. At least the prequel was decent enough to give me phone calls I could listen to in the other room while exploring

17) Nearly no incentive for exploring nor nothing to explore.

18) the default grenade is a piece of ♥♥♥♥--good thing there's plenty of alternate ones that are useful



The game kept getting worse and worse as I progressed. For reference the hospital early on was amazing and the schoolyard about halfway into it was really great. It's just a little too tedious and samey. Thankfully this game improved the abysmal flashlight from the first game. I hated that ♥♥♥♥ so much. Huerp gotta wait in the dark 10 seconds before I can illuminate this dark-♥♥♥ hospital. Screw that.

If you haven't already played the FEAR games then don't. You aren't missing anything noteworthy.

reviewText: The game is pretty much running through average, uninteresting levels and shooting generic looking foes with occasional supernatural stuff happening, like Alma or ghosts coming at you.  There's also a big deformed guy that can resurrect the dead, but those enemies appear very little in this game.  The game does have some cool weapons like a gun that instantly kills foe and deskin them as well as their flesh, but that doesnt appear until close to the end.  There isn't really anything scary or even startling in this game either, just jumps scares at most.  It doesn't help that when something that is suppose to be scary coming at you, you can just shoot it, even the ghosts.  The parts when your in a mec-suit are pretty cool.  Story wise it was just that you were  part of and experiment to make special telestetic soldiers like your character in the last game, which is why Alma is coming after you.  The other characters are just your standard soldier characters with no real personality.  You can get more of the story with logs and journals that you can find out throughout the game.  In conclusion, I though the game was alright but nothing special.

reviewText:
I want to write a review of this game because I think everyone need to know what will get when play this game.
I played F.E.A.R., F.E.A.R.:Extraction Point and F.E.A.R.:Perseus Mandate a few weeks ago. I love them. They scared me a few times and I enjoyed it. The story (specially the F.E.A.R. and the Extraction Point) was really good. The mixture between scares and fights was really good, and the notes on the story gave you a good perspective about what was happening. So, with that in mind, I began to play F.E.A.R. 2.

Oh, what an error.
The game is practically everything shooting, shooting, and more shooting. There are a few little low quality scares in the first half of the game, but the next hours is only bullets for everyone in really big (and boring) combats.
The notes are practically irrelevant. Some little details, or things you really pass to know.
Also, the story is... not interesting at all.

And then, I finished it. So, I played my recently bought (in the Halloween Steam Sales) F.E.A.R. 2 DLC. It couldn't be worse.
Oh, yes, it can.
There's practically no story. Only more bullets for everyone. There are no scares. Only guns.
And the final combat was really boring.

Summing up, the only good points of the game were seeing (only a few times in the first half) little Alma with good graphics and the possibility to pilot (but only two times in F.E.A.R. 2 and once in the DLC) an armored robot. No more, no less.

That's all about this game.

reviewText:
Despite having loved the first FEAR, its sequel is a seriously mixed bag.  The weapons are fairly satisfying, although the energy weapon and laser are stupidly awkward.  Gunplay in general still feels right, but the AI lacks the level of skill and more believable squad tactics that made the gunfights in original so dynamic and enjoyable.  Things feel much more scripted now, which while not necessarily bad, certainly makes for less engaging fights overall.

This almost goes without saying, but the game looks far better than the original. but it generally lacks the same unnerving tension that FEAR managed to create so regularly.  It definitely has its moments, to be sure, but it's far more sporadic.  Put differently, a lot of the scares (jump or otherwise) felt extremely formulaic at this point, with even sightings of Alma being generally unremarkable.

There were definitely some good (albeit disturbing) revelations--like the purpose of the school, or the extent of the experiments on Alma, the prototypes, and all the would-be candidates for the Program--but a lot of it still felt a bit perfunctory to me.  Maybe it's because a lot of the mystery was gone by that point.

I don't want to give it away, but I found the ending totally unexpected, disturbing, but also appropriate to the kind of dark, adult story being told--particularly considering its many troublesome implications.  However, my liking" of the ending and FEAR2 overall was also predicated on FEAR3 finally connecting all the dots in a satisfying and sufficiently harrowing way
date: which it most definitely did not do.\n\nI'm seriously torn here

reviewText: First of all compliments to the great game engine. Its shooting physics and gun play are very well done. The campaign plays just like Half-Life 2, with the story being told in the same way. Only difference is that there's random hallucinations mixed in at appropriate times. These are very well-done and although not scary, they create a great, mysterious atmosphere. The biggest disappointment is that there are no ranked multiplayer matches (2011), with only 1 or 2 unranked servers online at any given time. It's a shame since the multiplayer has potential to be fun and perhaps more polished than F.E.A.R. Combat's. The story is short with a lack of varied environments and gameplay. However, what you do get is of fairly decent quality and there's nothing like it out there. I played the demo on Xbox 360 and on PC before purchasing and it's quite clear that this game was made for the PC judging by the wealth of buttons in this game. Overall it's a decent game but not good value for money.

reviewText: FEAR 2 is a lazy, boring mess. The game's trite brand of jumpscare gorefest horror is shallow and clumsy, complementing the nonsensically stupid plot. The gameplay's not much better, with the most generic and mediocre arsenal of weaponry you can imagine scattered about yawn-inducing linear maps filled with the same enemies over and over again. Eventually the sensory overload of obnoxious sudden loud sounds and nauseating screen flashes may trigger a migraine in the player. There is nothing that FEAR 2 does that isn't done better in some other game, and even fans of the first game will find that this sequel falls short of the original in every respect.

reviewText:
Huge fan of the F.E.A.R series. F.E.A.R 2 is defintaly the best out of the 3. F.3.A.R was ok but strafed out of the horror segments too much and was just an all-rounder action shooter.

F.E.A.R 2 has a good balance between fright and fight. Beefy accurate weapons with rate of fire options plus grenade types. The graphics are decent enough for a 2009 game and was quite demanding for PC power back in its prime.

F.E.A.R 2 has outstanding animation in the enemies such as interacting with the enviroments to provide cover, dashing through windows or vaulting over ledges. Its so detailed if they set on fire near a ledge they will frail over and jump off in a panic or getting a shotgun slug to the chest, stagger back and think what the hell just hit them. Theres also the camoflague assassins that will roll around, backflip off walls and such to try and dazzle you before striking.

Then theres Alma. The key character that will stalk and haunt you as you play. She seems to have techincal connections with your crosshair as where ever you look she will appear before you in rigid postions before leaping towards you.

However there are things I am not happy with and thats the controls. The weapon selection can be quite messy, the ability to lean left and right from the original f.e.a.r has been taken out and also doesnt seem to be compatible with gaming mice as it only registers 2 mouse buttons which is terrible to say f.e.a.r could register 5.

reviewText:
I'm not going to waste time trying to make this post presentable, so here's a stream of consciousness (all comparisons are held against F.E.A.R. 1):

Dirty dirty console port, cell shaded graphics do not fit the theme, aiming feels inaccurate, the AI is stupider, there are no graphics settings other than to change the resolution, spawn points are blatantly obvious and depressingly-purposefully annoying, the game speed is slow enough where you don't even need slo mo (fear1 is so fast you actually need it), overall it's too easy to really get into combat yet I get instakilled frequently by things I can't see (enemies spawn right behind you). FEAR1 had sprawling levels where squads could strategically engage you (or be engaged by you)- FEAR2 is all cheap spawn points in linear, uninspired level design. Ammo is dropped every two inches, it can't differentiate between left CTRL and right CTRL (fear1 could), it bugs out if you press too many keys at once (it often gets stuck strafing right, it often doesn't register keypresses, etc). Moreover the story is filled with cheap thrills and the plot is insanely stupid- they've never heard of less is more". And the way alma is rendered is also less scary.

FEAR1's plot wasn't a masterpiece by any stretch; it had some really good and unique ideas in the meat of the story
date: but the frame-plot / getting to the meat of the story was pretty blatantly stupid. However it was at least *paced*; seems to me like they just wanted to play with some neat horror ideas and didn't really care too much about the rest of the plot- any excuse to get the player alone in some creepy environments would do. The game is about exploring ideas
recommended: and it is about exploring Alma's backstory; clearly not a lot of effort was put into leading up to that. Knowing that the plot was largely bad
hoursPlayed:
they interspersed truly intriguing elements along the way and approached the more interesting ideas *slowly*.

FEAR2's approach to storytelling is to have some guy call you up and explain just about everything to you. There's no suspense or pacing. It's just... all bad.

-------------------------------------
F.E.A.R. 2 Reborn DLC
-------------------------------------
This one really builds you up just to let you down- in the beginning

this game...
this game was so so so so disappointing to be fair to anyone who reads this im just going to flag this all as a spoiler cause it's that bad.

I really wanted to like this game, i really wanted to like the fear series but the promises and expectations this game promised are commmmmmmmplete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. First off this game should not be called FEAR, it should be called scripted events you wont notice but we will make your HUD twitch to tell you it is happening". Also the smart UI of NPCs is complete trash and it doesn't become more difficult when the damn NPCs continue to ANNOUNCE WHAT THEY ARE DOING "gernade out!" WELL I GUESS I WILL MOVE. The story is so thin and tries to give back story to Alma by sending you to her elementary school and trying to showcase how she is a victim of the experiments on her and she was just different. And yeah thats fine i guess if you just showed me like a short cinematic that detailed this instead of making me walk through repetative buildings and terrible outdated combat scenarios i would have appreciated that.
but the finale... after everything that game made me walk through the ending wasn't just terrible it was kind of offensive.

You get ♥♥♥♥♥ by the ghost of Alma

yup it happens she ties you down to a chair and induces halucinations on you and inbetween the final fight you see flashing cut scenes of her riding you and after the fight she appears before you magical pregnant. after seeing that I was done with the series and have made a promise to never play another FEAR.

reviewText:
Right of the bat I wanna say I didn't beat this game and I have no intenssions of doing so.
But I watched a let's play of it and played the first stage.

Graphics:
Graphics is way better then the first one and it is alot cleaner" but that does not help the game.
The game is supossed to be a horror game but it is a joke here I jumped oncew or twice from a jump scare but other then that nothing realy looked horrefiing to me.
With everything so clean nothing is left for the imagination and we are alot better at scareing ourself then anyone else.
So the atmosfer is lacking.
Yes blood and gore is horrefieing but if you spray it everywhere it just looks like someone ran around and droped red påaint everywhere.

Combat:
Combat is everywhere everything else got sacrificed for the combat and I personaly do not think it is a good way to go for something that is supposed to be horror.
But for oldschool shooter lover would like this title as there are no regen only helth and armor pick ups

Story:
The story is very lacking there are bits and pieces but nothing mayor the only thing you will miss is right at the end nothing else matters and I am not going to spoil that here.

Summery:
Do not pick this up if what you look for is a horror game cause it is not scary and utterly boring in that respect but if you want an old shooter style game set in abit darker setting this is something for you.
Thats what I think anyway."

reviewText: I saw comments saying this was distinctly lower quality than the original game and its expansions, but I personally found FEAR 2 to be much more fun than the first and it provided a fairly diverse gaming experience in terms of varied locations, a more healthy selection of enemy types (though still largely clones and mercs), and the plot was far more interesting, even a little spine tingling. The level designs featured rich detail and I appreciated that both objectives and exits were more clearly defined. The makers also kept things from getting overly repetitive by staggering sequences where you use Avatar-like power armor and arenas where you're forced to use your sniping skills. However, the character dialogue was stilted and crammed with poorly utilized profanity, and you have no means to alter the progression of events. In the end, I thought it was a mixed bag much like the original, but still a genuinely entertaining experience and with some very impressive visual flourishes.

reviewText:
Do I recommend F.E.A.R 2: Project Origin? Yes I do!

Warning: Spoilers ahead

Now, Alma was creepy as heck in the first F.E.A.R game, being a little girl in a red dress.
But F.E.A.R 2 took it to a new freaking level. In this game, Alma is an little girl , same as in F.E.A.R but later, near the end
she turned into an teen-adult woman with hair covering her boobs. Some of the scares were TERRIFYING!! Others were weak,
anyway to make this short

Pros:
25% Strong scares
Terrifying villian
Good AI
Good controls
Good graphics

Cons:
75% Weak scares
Small variety of weapons
Not threatening enimies
Too much fighting with soldiers
O.K storyline

So I guess because this is a horror game, alot of the scares are weak.
And that makes it a 'No' for me

6/10 Almaaaaaaa

reviewText: Don't listen to all the haters.  This is a solid single player FPS gaming experiance.  THe mutiplayer is meh, and people who claim this game has horror is wrong.  I played FEAR 1 and all the DLC, then played FEAR 2 and DLC.  My opinion is not the same as everyone who claims FEAR one is better in every way... I disagee.  Both games are just FPS, kill the other guys shooting at you... then they mix in some scares and ghosts, but this is just shoot people who shoot at you.  I feel FEAR 2 does this better than FEAR 1.  Yes, you lose having quick save and mutiple saves, no lean.  HOWEVER, you gain better levels that look better and play better.  I enjoyed using all the guns, unlike part 1 with cheating AI, I just ran in everyroom with a shot gun, did slow mo and killed everything.  This game I actually liked hiding and shoot with all the guns.  Overall FEAR 2 is more solid and fun, Part 1 felt annoying towards the end.  If you are a story person... part 1 is better than part 2.  IMO

reviewText: This is a surprisingly good shooter. It's got the old school health and armor system but there are always health and armor pickups in plain sight between firefights so you never have to backtrack to find more health. The weapons are really nice. You can hold 4 weapons so you can pretty much grab whatever is lying around and not worry about being poorly equipped for the next part and there are only really 1 or 2 weapons that suck and not worth grabbing. Enemies always drop plenty of ammo so you can just fire away. One thing that makes this game stand out gameplay wise is the slow-motion ability. It feels really nice to use, looks cool and helps to stop the game from feeling like a generic shooter. Then there are the spooky parts. While not necessarily scary they do really add to the environment of the game. The game looks very good at max settings and is very well detailed and surprisingly full of colour. While it doesn't massively deviate from the standard shooter genre at the time it shows that shooters can still be different and fun. I give it 4 brain aneurysms out of 5.
